content: <!DOCTYPE html>Two Animations + TextAWE will change the game for wind energyOnly the outer third of the wings contribute to 80% of energy production. AWE only moves in the efficient area and uses10x fewer materialsCheaper transportation and installation equals3x faster Return of InvestmentOperating at greater altitudes with more wind increases full load hours by 60%The existing AWE technology can mainly be divided into four groups. There are rigid versus flexible and ground-gen versus fly-gen. The flexible kite type is cheaper to produce and can survive crashes, but it has lower aerodynamics. The fixed kite type has higher aerodynamics, and a longer lifetime as long as it does not collide with anything.Fly-gen kite generates energy in the air with propellers and is theoretically more efficient than ground-gen, but it is also riskier because the expensive equipment is flying around in the air.

We are looking for partners and all sorts of collaborations.Whether you are an experienced engineer, a surfer dude, or a curious student, please reach out! We can collaborate, team up, or fund your next student project. We are always interested in new perspectives and bright people!
Please reach out if you are an innovator!Airborne Wind Energy has the potential to disrupt the whole energy industry. It provides more stable energy with less down time at 10x lower cost. It will not only replace wind turbines. It will disrupt the fossil fuel industry.
Our technology has the potential to reduce carbon emissions on a global scale, but we need you on our team to fully develop the disruptive technology.
Join us now!Our People

Highly driven by the green agenda, I want to develop radical new green tech. I experience from several research based startups and have worked in a hard tech startup.I am ready to make bold bets, because I believe it is riskier not to. Incremental improvements won’t stop the climate crisis.
title: Carl Lassen

content:
Connecting the best ideas from researchers, engineers, and innovatorsMain ArchitectureRigid versus FlexibleThe flexible kite type is cheaper to produce and can survive crashes, but it has lower aerodynamics. The fixed kite type has better aerodynamics, and a longer lifetime. The fixed kite has a higher potential, but also comes with lger risks.
Fly-gen versus Gound-genThe fly-gen kite generates the energy in the air with propellers. Theoretically, it has a higher efficiency, but it is also riskier because the expensive equipment is flying around in the air. There are some promising startups that failed because they ran out of money too quickly when testing their kite. The ground-gen kite is safer as the expensive equipment is on the ground. It produces energy when the kite pulls a wire that makes a turbine spin around. The ground-gen losses though 20% of the produced energy, when it pulls back the kite before it can create energy again.
Fly-genTurbine placementAccording to a study by Filippo Trevisi, Gianni Cassoni, Mac Gaunaa, and Lorenzo Fagiano (2025), it is most efficient to place turbines on the wing tips and rotate them inboard down. There are though many aspects that should be considered.
Read the whole article here: Concurrent aerodynamic design of the wing and the turbines of airborne wind energy systems
PreviousNext
I believe we need to do things radically different
title: Carl Lassen

content:
According to a study by Filippo Trevisi, Gianni Cassoni, Mac Gaunaa, and Lorenzo Fagiano (2025), it is most efficient to place turbines on the wing tips and rotate them inboard down. There are though many aspects that should be considered.
Read the whole article here: Concurrent aerodynamic design of the wing and the turbines of airborne wind energy systems
title: Turbine placement and rotation direction

content: We develop green 10x technologiesWith a mission to disrupt the fossil fuel industry, we aim to make technologies that are 10x more efficient.Airborne Wind Energy has that potential.It is a completely new technology and lots of experimentation is needed to make it work.If you playful spirit and are ready to fight climate change, please join us!Why we need green 10x technologiesIn 1896, Swedish chemist Svante Arrhenius discovered global warming. 130 years later, the climate crisis is common knowledge. Yet, the carben emissions are still rising to new records.Even rich modern democracies and modern technologies are still inadequate to reach net zero. We need new strategies and the clock is ticking…We need to make big bets. Not because we love gambling, but because its riskier not to. Status quo is not an option. We need 10x improvements!We don’t know which technologies will save the world, but we believe that Airborne Wind Energy has the potential change the world to the better!No matter which green tech you believe in, we encourage you to develop radical 10x technologies!TimelineDecember 2025Spread the wordWebsite PublishedWe need as many people as possible to work on this. Therefore, it was first priority to publish our website to spread the word and progress. November 2025PrototypeOur first kite-wingCutted, bended and glued an old election poster into the first prototype. It was unstable and without electronics. It would probably help to move the center of gravity forward.1992HistoryDeveloped countries agree to return their emissions to 1990 levels166 coutries signed the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) with the goal of "stabilization of greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere at a level that would prevent dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate system".1990HistoryGlobal warming was proved by United Nations IPCCThe IPCC Report concludes that temperatures have risen by 0.3-0.6C over the last century.1896HistoryGlobal warming was discoveredSwedish chemist Svante Arrhenius discovered global warming.
